title: German Adjective Declension
description: Comprehensive guide to German adjective declension patterns

content.content:
# German Adjective Declension

German adjectives change their endings based on three factors:
1. The case of the noun (Nominative, Accusative, Dative, Genitive)
2. The gender of the noun (Masculine, Neuter, Feminine, Plural)
3. The type of article used (Definite, Indefinite, or No Article)

## Weak Declension (After Definite Articles)

| Case       | Masculine | Neuter    | Feminine  | Plural    |
|------------|-----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| Nominative | **-e**    | **-e**    | **-e**    | -en       |
| Accusative | -en       | **-e**    | **-e**    | -en       |
| Dative     | -en       | -en       | -en       | -en       |
| Genitive   | -en       | -en       | -en       | -en       |

*(Remember the "Oklahoma" pattern for the **-e** endings!)*

## Mixed Declension (After Indefinite Articles)

| Case       | Masculine | Neuter    | Feminine  | Plural    |
|------------|-----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| Nominative | **-er**   | **-es**   | **-e**    | -en       |
| Accusative | -en       | **-es**   | **-e**    | -en       |
| Dative     | -en       | -en       | -en       | -en       |
| Genitive   | -en       | -en       | -en       | -en       |

*(Note the strong endings -er/-es in the "Oklahoma" pattern where the indefinite article has no ending.)*

## Strong Declension (Without Articles)

| Case       | Masculine | Neuter    | Feminine  | Plural    |
|------------|-----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| Nominative | **-er**   | **-es**   | **-e**    | **-e**    |
| Accusative | **-en**   | **-es**   | **-e**    | **-e**    |
| Dative     | **-em**   | **-em**   | **-er**   | **-en**   |
| Genitive   | **-en**   | **-en**   | **-er**   | **-er**   |

*(Adjective takes the definite article endings, except for Genitive Masc/Neut where it's -en.)*
